bibl.title: Letter from Laura Wood to James E. Peabody, February 2, 1942

div1.p: Wood reports to Peabody about Emilie and Blossom Reed and the illnesses of Andrus and Kissinger. She requests information about the pensions for the participants and their families.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Wood to James E. Peabody, February 2, 1942
div1.opener:
FROM JAMES E. PEABODY
1338 19th St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.,
February 2, 1942.
Mr. James E. Peabody,
281 Lowell Avenue,
Newtonville, Mass.
Dear Mr. Peabody:
div1.p:
Thank you for your kind letter. I am so glad that mine finally
found its way to you.

To answer your question about Mrs. Reed and Blossom. Mrs. Reed
has just had her 86th. birthday and is quite alive. Blossom has been
very ill and was in the Walter Reed Hospital all spring and summer,
but now appears quite restored to health. I have not seen either of
them, because General Reed, Walter Reed's son, prefers not to have me
bother them under the circumstances--i. e. Blossom's recent illness--
but Dr. Hench went to Mrs. Reed's birthday party, so it is from him
that I learned that they are living at the Burlington Hotel, 1120 Ver-
mont Avenue, N.W.

I am distressed to learn of the seriousness of Mr. Kissinger's
condition. Mr. Andrus, too, is bed-ridden, but seems to keep busy and
cheerful. I had a letter from him just this morning.

General Kean has been my most valued adviser during my work on
this book. He is endlessly patient about explaining and answering
questions. Dr. Kelly's acquaintance with Dr. Reed was slight, so he
has little information that does not already appear in his book.

I should like very much to see your account of Dr. Welch's part
in getting the Yellow Fever Bill through Congress, since I may write
an epilogue on the aftermath of the work, although the paltry allowances
first made, the squabbles and jealousies that developed make pretty sad !
reading, although relieved by other more cheerful things.
div1.closer: Sincerely, Laura Wood. (Author of “Walter Reed, A Doctor in Uniform.”)
